cyclone.name: NESTOR
cyclone.current_location: about 155 miles east of Tampico, Mexico and 600 miles southwest of the mouth of the Mississippi River
cyclone.trajectory: Expected to turn northeast later today, accelerate across the north-central Gulf of Mexico, make landfall along the Florida Panhandle Friday night, then sweep northeastward across the southeastern U.S. and move offshore of the Mid-Atlantic coast late Sunday–Monday.

weather_observation.watch_coast: Mississippi/Alabama border eastward to Yankeetown, FL
weather_observation.warning_coast: Grand Isle, LA to the mouth of Pearl River and eastward to the Mississippi/Alabama border, and west Florida coast to the Ochlockonee River
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Northern Gulf Coast, north-central Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas; Mid-Atlantic states may see peripheral effects late this weekend
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Unlikely (forecast generally under 2 inches for Mid-Atlantic)
weather_observation.wind: Occasional gusty northeast winds possible Monday as the system passes offshore; sustained tropical-storm-force winds are unlikely (≤3 % chance).
weather_observation.storm_surge: None expected for the Delaware River and upper Delaware Bay.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands of rain could bring 1–2 inches to the Philadelphia area late Sunday into Monday, causing ponding on terminal surfaces and possible minor delays.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Brief reduction in visibility due to heavy showers; minor river-and-tidal fluctuations but no significant surge or wave action expected.
